ReportSection.title: 2023 Healthy Aging Canada (HAC) Catalyst Funding Program - Application
ReportSection.Static:
The 2023 Catalyst Funding Program in Healthy Aging aims to identify and support emerging research in technology-enabled healthy aging, foster networking and collaboration, and build capacity in aging innovation research in Canada.

It is expected that small-scale projects or pilot studies funded through this call will provide a foundation for future larger research projects or funding applications. Examples of supported activities for this call include:
  • Feasibility studies aiming to generate preliminary data, observations, or knowledge;
  • Advancement of novel products, including technologies, with the potential for significant impact, but that may be currently unsupported by proof of concept or preliminary data;
  • Development of new tools, methodologies, protocols, theoretical models or frameworks;
  • Planning and/or development activities of expert teams (e.g., multi-disciplinary, trans-disciplinary, etc.) coming together to address healthy aging research priorities; and
  • Secondary analyses of existing data sets to improve the evidence for decision-making and create new knowledge.

PRIORITY AREAS

  • Innovative solutions that empower older adults to live safe, healthy, and socially connected lives within their homes and/or communities.
  • Innovative solutions focused on the role, health and well-being of care partners supporting older adults.
  • Building safer, more accessible, or more connected communities.
  • Development and accelerated dissemination of best practices, guidelines, or standards.
  • Solutions that include and meet the needs of vulnerable and equity-deserving groups of people.
  • Quality improvement studies that investigate novel and innovative ways to improve the lives of older Canadians.

APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS

Proposals will be a maximum of 2,500 words (approx. 5 pages) in length, excluding lay summary, budget materials and bios. They must:
  • Relate to the development of technology-enabled solutions or a novel technology to support healthy aging, which can include complementary social and healthcare innovations (e.g., new service-delivery models, policy recommendations, and prevention strategies) related to the solution.
  • Outline how at least one of the priority areas listed above will be addressed by the project.
  • Map to at least one of AGE-WELL’s 8 Challenge Areas.
  • Include long-term (multi-year) and short-term objectives that situate the present one-year project within a larger project plan.
  • Consider equity, diversity, inclusion (EDI) and indigeneity in terms of research design, team composition, and impact of proposed solution.
  • Include a plan to engage older adults and/or care partners in the research.
  • Outline how sex and gender might be taken into account in their research, methods, analysis, and interpretation, or explain why sex and/or gender are not applicable to the research proposal.

Please review carefully the information and updates in the complete call for proposals: https://agewell-nce.ca/catalyst-funding-program-in-healthy-aging

ReportSection.title: B. RESEARCH PLAN
ReportSection.name: Research Plan
ReportSection.ReportItem:
The research plan should provide a framework for the operation of the project. Details of project alignment to special funding streams identified in Section A, if applicable, should be included in this section.

Projects must consider equity, diversity, inclusion and indigeneity in terms of research design, team composition and impact of proposed solution.

Applicants are encouraged to review the following resources when considering how to integrate EDI in their research: CIHR Equity, diversity and inclusion resources.

1. Background and Rationale [Maximum of 500 words, approx. 1 page (excluding reference list)]

Describe the proposed activities and the current state-of-the-art in the field, including gaps in knowledge, solutions, and needs that will be addressed by your research. Please include appropriate references as a separate uploaded document (appended in next section).

Eligible projects must relate to the development of technology-enabled solutions or a novel technology to support healthy aging, which can include complementary social and healthcare innovations (e.g., new service-delivery models, policy recommendations, and prevention strategies) related to the solution.

{$item}

2. Objectives, Methods and Deliverables (Maximum of 1,500 words, approx. 3 pages)

2.1. Objectives

Provide an overview of research plans, including the scope of the one-year project, as well as a brief statement of longer-term objectives (multi-year) that situate the present project within a larger project plan.

Describe how the priority area identified in Section A will be addressed by this project.

Identify and describe your research questions and objectives for the proposed one-year project.

2.2. Approach and methods

Describe the approaches and methodologies that will be used in the project to achieve its objectives.

This section must describe how objectives identified in section 2.1 will be met by the proposed one-year program of research.

Describe how older adults and/or care partners will be involved in the research, including co-creation methods.

Describe how sex and gender will be considered in the research, methods, analysis and interpretation.

Applicants should refer to notes in the preamble to this section on addressing equity, diversity and inclusion.

2.3. Innovation and impact

Describe the novelty and originality of the proposed program of research.

Describe the anticipated scientific outputs of this research. This may include the relationship of the research project to similar work conducted elsewhere in Canada and internationally.

2.4. Timelines and deliverables/milestones

Describe major milestones and deliverables for this one-year project.

{$item}

3. Project Team and Partnerships (Maximum of 250 words, plus table)

Projects are encouraged to include team members from more than one discipline. Projects must identify a Knowledge User with relevant lived experience and expertise. Applicants should consider contributing to the development of trainees or Highly Qualified Personnel (HQP) through their inclusion as team members.

Applicants are encouraged to consider their processes of identifying, recruiting and selecting research team personnel based on equity, diversity and inclusion best practices as one means to enhance excellence in research, training and outreach.

Applicants are encouraged to include partner organizations in their project plans, including as part of any knowledge mobilization or commercialization planning. Such organizations should be described in the application, even where the partnership is at a very early stage of development. For reporting purposes, all partnership activities should be described in the application.

Briefly describe the expertise, role and contributions of all project personnel listed in the table below.

{$item}

Project Personnel

List all identified project team members, including Project Lead(s), Co-Investigators, Collaborators, Highly Qualified Personnel (HQP), Knowledge User(s) and Partners (Glossary of Funding-Related Terms). A brief bio (free form, maximum 1,500 words) for identified Project Lead(s) must be appended in the next section.

For applications involving Indigenous populations (including First Nations, Inuit and Métis), the research team must include at least one member who self-identifies as Indigenous (First Nations, Inuit or Métis) or demonstrates a track record of meaningful and culturally safe involvement with Indigenous Peoples.

{$item}

4. Budget and Budget Justification (Budget spreadsheet plus 250 word budget justification)

AGE-WELL and CFN abide by the funding rules of the Tri-Council Agencies and the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) in particular. Please consult the Tri-Agency Guide on Financial Administration about eligibility, eligible grant expenses, partner contributions etc.
